awd_titl_txt: Preparing Next Generation Scientists through Teacher and Extension Science Partnerships and Schoolyard Citizen Science Investigations in Elementary Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
With the release of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), great interest and demand has been placed on the design and development of high quality, NGSS-aligned professional development. The Standards' Three-Dimensional Learning Framework has also required more creative and non-conventional professional development models to support the changing landscape of science education and instruction. This project intends to address this critical need at the elementary school level through an innovative collaborative professional development model. The University of New Hampshire, in partnership with New Hampshire Schools, will bring together two groups of educators - elementary school teachers (formal) and cooperative extension science volunteers (informal) -  to create a community-based professional development partnership that improves educators' self-efficacy, science content knowledge, and instructional practice. The model builds on the premise that both groups have expertise that can be shared and collaboratively developed. Together, with an interdisciplinary team of education experts, the teacher and extension science volunteers will learn how to design and implement appropriate, NGSS-aligned science lessons with elementary school students through locally relevant community-based, citizen science projects. This is a particularly novel approach. Though both groups are highly regarded for their contributions to elementary science education in their respective domains (i.e., formal and informal settings), few, if any, existing models examine the potential impact of partnering the groups together in a shared professional development experience.  

This Early Stage Design and Development project will partner and engage approximately 50 elementary school teachers (grades 2nd-5th) and 30 extension science volunteers from urban and rural New Hampshire in the year-long professional development program. Over a three-year period, the target groups will participate in workshops and citizen science investigations related to biodiversity, soil science, stream ecology, plant phenology and/or wildlife habitats. Program content and activities will be aligned to the Next Generation Science Standards and New Hampshire State Standards. A mixed methods approach will be employed to explore three aspects of the elementary school teacher?s efficacy over time. The research questions will seek to address: (1) What changes occur in elementary school teachers? self-efficacy teaching science and in their ability to integrate NGSS science practices through locally relevant citizen science projects? (2) What shifts occur in teacher content knowledge and how do the shifts in teacher content knowledge relate to the changes in teacher self-efficacy? (3) What is the process of collaboration between extension science volunteers and teachers? Data will be collected through surveys, interviews, and documents/artifacts. Formative and summative evaluations will be provided by an Advisory Board of experts with a broad range of relevant expertise. The outcomes of this project have the potential to impact professional development approaches across the country and will support the goal of increasing public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology by optimizing elementary teachers' implementation of locally-relevant citizen science in their classrooms.  Similarly, by promoting a connection between the volunteers and local schools, this innovative model provides a new avenue for extension science volunteers to impact their communities.

The project is supported by the Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12), which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
Given the new vision of K-12 science education put forth by Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), teachers' approach to science instruction is expected to significantly change, such as teaching content through students' engagement with scientific practices. Consequently, there is an increasing demand for professional development (PD) that builds both K-5 teachers' science content knowledge and their ability to integrate the science practices into the classroom. We designed the Schoolyard SITES program, a school-community STEM teacher PD model. The Schoolyard SITES program partners New Hampshire elementary teachers with University of New Hampshire Cooperative Extension science-based, volunteers to bring locally relevant citizen science projects to their students. Schoolyard SITES addresses an identified need for PD that implements the vision of NGSS.

The Schoolyard SITES PD model is a 3-pronged collaboration among elementary teachers, Extension science volunteers, and university science education and citizen science professionals. This 3-way collaboration is central to building both content knowledge and  confidence in our teacher participants. According to the model, volunteers are situated as experts in local environmental science topics. The teachers are positioned to be the experts in K-5 teaching. In addition to serving as content experts, the volunteers also serve as role models, demonstrating their passion for investigating the world and their knowledge of life or Earth science community-based topics. The university specialists facilitate the PD workshop series and guide the collaborative learning experience over the course of one school year. As a result of the several years of project implementation, UNH specialists published the Schoolyard SITES Curriculum Workbook  and Guide to Choosing Locally Relevant Citizen Science Projects for the Classroom in order to further support educators with the design process as they craft a schoolyard citizen science curriculum.

Our research study focused on the following questions:

1. What collaboration skills do teachers and volunteers focus on while working on a successful interdisciplinary collaboration?

2. What are the changes that are observed in elementary school teachers' self-efficacy (confidence) in teaching science and their ability to integrate NGSS science practices through a locally-relevant citizen science project?

We used a mixed-method research approach that incorporated pre- and post-surveys, interviews, and document analysis of curriculum units produced through the teacher-volunteer partnership. The pre-, post-surveys were designed to measure collaboration skills (e.g., honest communication) and included the reliable and validated Science Teaching Efficacy Belief Instrument (STEBI-A) to measure teachers' self-efficacy (confidence) in science teaching.

Thirty-three elementary teachers from eight New Hampshire school districts (i.e., Bedford, Manchester, Nashua, Oyster River Community, Portsmouth, Rochester, Somersworth, & Stratham) and 19 Extension Science Volunteers, with backgrounds ranging from Master Gardeners to Marine Docents, participated in the Schoolyard SITES research study and PD program. Teacher-volunteer teams designed and taught 20 classroom citizen science projects to approximately 575 elementary students, grades K through 5, in New Hampshire. These curricula are mainly focused on life and Earth science disciplinary content, with some projects addressing physical science content. In general, these citizen science projects were taught by the teacher-volunteer teams during the late spring, engaging their elementary students in schoolyard investigations while actively engaging them in the NGSS science practices.

Our study indicates that teachers and volunteers understand that school-community partnerships are both important, and beneficial, to science learning. Overall, the teachers and volunteers cited several skills that helped support a successful collaboration. Teachers and volunteers indicated that active listening, honest communication, the ability to compromise and work through differences, vulnerability, and sharing personal stories are important components of a successful collaboration. Teachers were able to provide more nuanced, or very detailed, explanations for each of the collaboration skills (e.g., listening, honest communication, compromise) after completing the Schoolyard SITES program. In addition, our findings suggest that teachers' confidence teaching science significantly increased, and their integration of NGSS science practices in the classroom improved, after enacting their co-designed curriculum. The top NGSS science practices reported by teachers were students' carrying out investigations, analyzing and interpreting data, constructing explanations, and engaging in scientific argumentation. The Schoolyard SITES PD model has constructed a pathway for community science-based volunteers and teachers to build a sustainable partnership, so as to engage elementary students in citizen science and authentic science practices. Ultimately, our research indicates that the Schoolyard SITES is an impactful PD model for teacher education with respect to building teachers' confidence and enactment of reform-minded science instruction.
